Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. 

Students raved about this course, finding it interesting and engaging. Though it was a three hour, once-a-week course, students reported that they were “never once bored” and several students even described it as “one of the best classes” that they have taken. The dialogue nature of the class helped them learn the material and “understand the nuances between different topics.” Though the workload and assigned reading for the class was heavy, students learned a great deal. 

Professor Rongione was unanimously praised in reviews as a “lovable” and “funny” professor, who “cares very much for his students and the subject he teaches.” Professor Rongione gave every student opportunities to speak, and kept them on their toes by cold calling and challenging statements, a method which was “very effective in getting everyone to participate and know each other.” Students applauded his ability to stimulate student interest throughout the entire three-hour class period, while still covering all of the necessary material. Students described Professor Rongione as an “A+” and “the best professor at Penn.”

This class was taken mainly by Wharton students. It fulfills part of the Societal Environment general requirement. Though the amount learned was great, some students questioned how much they actually improved their “ethical base.” The work and reading was heavy for this class, but this was matched by the large amount of information the students learned throughout the semester. The class was very participation heavy, so students must be diligent about the assigned reading. Overall, students highly recommended this course.

Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives.  Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business.  Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales, hiring and promotion, financial management, corporate pollution, product safety, and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

By and large, students felt the course was interesting and highly relevant. The course made heavy use of case studies and discussion, which one student called “the best way to study ethics.” Many recommended the class to other students and one even acknowledged that the course was one of their “favorite core classes.”  

Students felt Professor Sarachan was highly engaging, though some thought he was a bit monotone and neutral. There was an agreement that Professor Sarachan was particularly good at facilitating case discussions, shaping different scenarios, and challenging students.  One student mentioned that Professor Sarachan “respects opinions and communicates theories well.”  

Students did not mention the difficulty of assessments, but they felt that the reading load was reasonable at approximately 2-3 articles per class.  Another student called the workload “wonderfully light.”  Students who enjoy discussion-based classes would enjoy the class. This course is one of the three classes than can fulfill the two-course societal environment requirement.

Legal Studies 210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures.

Students thought that the course was “interesting” and a “must in today’s competitive, and often short-sighted, world.” The students also liked the use of real life examples in the class.

Nearly every student praised Professor Laufer, saying that “the class is great, but nothing compared to the professor.” Students particularly remarked that Professor Laufer did a great job keeping the class interesting, while conveying the material on ethics through classroom discussions. A few students remarked that they wished Professor Laufer had been a bit more organized in regard to class structure. 

Most students who took the class expected to do well, but some remarked that “it is hard to know what information will be tested.” Some students also remarked that the class debate led to too much competitiveness. This class, along with LGST 101 and BPUB 203, may be used to fulfill the societal environment requirement in Wharton.
